This extended note aims to capture the progress on vaccination programme before it is rolled out to the entire country (does not include R&D, clinic trials).    The China National Medicine Products Administration (MPA) has not formally approved the Sinopharm Inactivated vaccine to go to the market. However, the green light is anticipated in the next few days.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201214212000/https://weareunited.com.my/11515744/    On 24 June 2020, the MPA approved the emergency use of COVID-19 vaccine. Voluntary vaccination started on around 17 June. The first batch of receivers consisted mainly of key workers, including state-owned enterprise employees who must go overseas to countries where the pandemic hits hard; medical staff, epidemic-control staff, border force and other essential workers who keep cities running.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201214231804/https://finance.sina.com.cn/chanjing/cyxw/2020-11-18/doc-iiznezxs2537217.shtml    From mid-October, Zhejiang province has offered vaccines to ordinary citizens on a voluntary basis. The rationale has been that many cities in Zhejiang have export-oriented economies; for example, Yiwu city is the world centre for light industry commodity trading. Many wholesale merchants were keen on receiving vaccines so that they can travel to Latin America and Africa to inspect their businesses. See BBC reports below. By mid-November, Zhejiang had provided vaccines to some 743,000 people. Voluntary vaccines were paid by recipients. Two doses cost roughly 400 CNY plus a service charge of around 56 CNY, which altogether equals to approximately 70 USD.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201214231741/https://www.bbc.com/zhongwen/simp/chinese-news-54628714    As the vaccination programme is yet to roll out to the whole country, there is no national policy on who will get the vaccine first. However, Sichuan province, where the most recent cluster of infection was found, did publish a detailed plan to that sets out the order:    The first group to receive vaccines consists of people facing high risks of infection, including medical staffs with International assistance mission, national health emergency rescue team in Sichuan, fever clinic and frontline doctors and nurses, border control force, frontline health inspection and epidemic-control officials, students or workers going overseas, police force, frozen food industry workers, essential workers for keeping cities running, teachers, other medical staffs, doctors and nurses, community social workers. The first batch is estimated to have 2 million people. Vaccination for them has started and will finish within 2020.    The second group to receive vaccines mainly consists of vulnerable people, including elderly people and people with chronic diseases. Vaccination for them will start from early next year (January).    The third batch will open to the general public. Ordinary people are estimated to start receiving vaccines after the Chinese New Year (12 February 2021).    http://web.archive.org/web/20201214221555/https://www.sohu.com/a/437018675_114988    So far, vaccination is not and is unlike to be paid by social medical insurance funds in the future. The National Health Security Administration has cited laws and regulations as the justification that vaccination is a part of public health effort, which should be shouldered by public finance resources, rather than social medical insurance funds.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201214211226/https://www.sohu.com/a/425495553_114986    UAE and Bahrain have formally approved the Sinopharm vaccine on 9th and 13th December 2020 respectively.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201214231619/http://www.xinhuanet.com/2020-12/09/c_1126842251.htm  http://web.archive.org/web/20201214231549/http://www.xinhuanet.com/world/2020-12/14/c_1126855787.htm

These take on the form of transitionary and proportional.  Note: these restrictions are not as broad and not necessarily as strict as the PSBBs employed in the country in early 2020 (Apr and May).    In general: acc to the US Embassy in Indonesia: "While the government has lifted most restrictions regarding transit and daily activity, measures remain in place limiting large-scale gatherings and non-essential travel." https://web.archive.org/web/20201206224550/https://id.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/    Specific PSBB reports:  1. Banten Province: Proportional PSBB from Nov 20 to Dec 19, 2020 https://web.archive.org/web/20201206225136/https://republika.co.id/berita/qk2sxu484/psbb-di-provinsi-banten-diperpanjang-hingga-19-desember  2. West Java: Proportional PSBB in parts of West Java (Bogor City, Depok, Bekasi, and Bogor Regency) until Dec 23 2020: https://web.archive.org/web/20201206224926/https://indonesiaexpat.biz/news/transitional-psbb-dki-jakarta-and-proportional-psbb-west-java-extended/  3. Jakarta: Transitional PSBB extended till Dec 06: https://web.archive.org/web/20201206234145/https://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2020/11/23/jakarta-extends-transitional-psbb-amid-rising-covid-19-cases-health-protocol-violations.html    While not as universal and strict as the nation-wide PSBB employed by Indonesia in early 2020, these local patchwork of PSBBs give authorities to enact strict restrictions on public gatherings, workplace restrictions, including mass public prayers without any prior notice (restrictions can range from requiring social distancing ... to ... shutting down work places in select sectors).   The details of how strict such restrictions are at any given moment are under-reported. Below are examples of the most strictest restrictions i could find from such PSBBs, which have now been extended:    Example 1: Oct 27 2020; Jakarta Post: "Large-scale social restrictions in Bodebek, Jakarta extended"   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201101073623/https://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2020/10/27/large-scale-social-restrictions-in-bodebek-jakarta-extended.html    "Depok city (in West Java province) is the region with the highest number of COVID-19 cases with a total of 6,858 patients. Depok is now also classified as a red zone after the national COVID-19 task force upgraded its status as a region with a high risk of COVID-19 transmission. Therefore, the Depok administration will continue to impose a curfew for residents and business activities. With the curfew, residents’ activities cannot continue past 9 p.m., while businesses are allowed to stay open until 8 p.m. "Dine-ins at restaurants and food stalls will only be allowed until 6 p.m., while take away service is until 9:00 p.m.," said Depok city COVID-19 task force spokesperson, Dadang Wihana."    Example 2: The international legal blog/website Lexology.com reported on Sep 09 2020: "Jakarta Government Pulls the Emergency Brake and Reinstates Total Large-Scale Social Restrictions"; Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201206231657/https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=43457a21-1aed-4665-9057-0a4d9ee12d48    While this is not a news/govt agency, this article was the best example I could spot for what included in more recently enacted PSBBs in Indonesia:    "1. Non-essential office activities must be done from home. The governor of Jakarta emphasized that business actors should continue their business activities from home, not in the office.    2. Businesses in the 11 essential sectors stipulated in Jakarta Governor Regulation No. 33 of 2020 on the Implementation of Large-Scale Social Restrictions to Handle the Corona Virus Disease 2019 in Jakarta (as amended) can remain open with minimum operation. These 11 essential sectors are as follows: a) health; b) food and beverages; c) energy; d) communication and informatics technology; e) financial; f) logistics; g) hotels; h) construction; i) strategic industries (not specifically defined, so the Jakarta Governor has the discretion to further stipulate it) j) essential services (pelayanan dasar), public utilities and certain industries that are categorized as national vital objects (obyek vital nasional) and certain objects (obyek tertentu); k) daily necessity supplies (kebutuhan sehari-hari)    3. Business actors that have obtained a non-essential exceptional operational license (izin pengecualian operasi bidang non-esensial) must re-obtain the license from the government of Jakarta.    4. All entertainment/recreation, including malls (except daily needs stores in the malls), museums, zoos and public parks will be closed.    5. Students will continue to learn from home as schools remain closed.    6. Restaurants and cafes can continue to operate, but only to serve take-away and delivery orders (no dine-in service).    7. Local places of worship (that only serve people in the neighborhood) can still operate, but with strict protocols and provided that they are not located in red zones. Big/renowned worship places (that serve people from all over Jakarta) must be closed.    8. Activities that can gather a crowd, e.g., reunions and large family gatherings, must not be held.    9. Public transportation will be limited (in the number of vehicles and the time). In Jakarta, the odd and even private cars restrictions will temporarily be stopped.    10. The governor of Jakarta urges people to stay at home and not leave Jakarta unless there is an urgent need. Further, the Jakarta government is coordinating with the central government and the neighboring regional governments, such as Banten, to discuss the limitation of vehicles going in and out of Jakarta."

States implementing RMCO include Malacca, Pahang, Perlis, Sarawak, and Terengganu. Educational institutions remain closed until further notice.    The CMCO or even the enhanced movement control order continues in Kuala Lumpur, Sabah State, and specific localities in other states, including six districts in Selangor State, as well as parts of Johor, Kelantan, Negeri Sembilan, Penang, and Perak, through Dec. 20. In these places, all educational institutions are suspended.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201221170524/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/409741/malaysia-covid-19-restrictions-adjusted-in-most-states-as-of-dec-7-update-18
